Content: it doesn't contain the string `03e595e6e348e8d8571eef291a2bda3f4d5ee9c7be1d36991108a9815e86b9ed26 `

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: unless it was a spend to RQm8BNygniNVqVPRYXEosznRZ7uEiooqSm it wont have the pubkey in it. you cant validateaddress RQm8BNygniNVqVPRYXEosznRZ7uEiooqSm

Author: jl777c#5810

Author: lukechilds#2707

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I thought a TX contained the pubkey for inputs you're signing, and that was how you verify the signature, is that not correct?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: not a p2pkh that has the hash of the pubkey so you need to have the signature and the pubkey on the stack via scriptSig to allow the OP_EQUALVERIFY against the p2pkh scriptPubKey

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I know the recipient address is the hash of the pubkey for a P2PKH TX but I thought when you spend a P2PKH input you need to include your pubkey in the TX. How else can you verify it? And how do you "have the signature and the pubkey on the stack" without including the pubkey in the TX?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
I just checked, it does.
The `RQm8BNygniNVqVPRYXEosznRZ7uEiooqSm` pubkey is included in the raw TX I linked above. That was going `RQm8BNygniNVqVPRYXEosznRZ7uEiooqSm` -> `RMqevVxyUkgJdSqYEKj5CK4XcX5UvqFsyj `

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:

```
3044022022047c84f9dc59d57d54022b3a9aa61db2f78bea8edd513befacfb55439e560b02202d5b74c539b17a1785b10084556249fc9882778b8cf593a1eaaece6e6e2cc7e501 03e595e6e348e8d8571eef291a2bda3f4d5ee9c7be1d36991108a9815e86b9ed26
```

is everything after the space the stack?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: and in a normal P2PKH TX will that always be only the pubkey?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 03e595e6e348e8d8571eef291a2bda3f4d5ee9c7be1d36991108a9815e86b9ed26 <- pubkey

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the rmd160 of the pubkey needs to match the vout that is being spent

Author: luke#8628
Content:
Hey! Do I understand this correctly for how the DEX rewards are paid out?

1. Every time an atomic swap happens in BarterDEX, a 0.15% fee is charged to the Taker in the currency they are sending.
2. That fee is sent to an address in that currency owned by someone at Komodo 
3. Once enough fees are collected, the fees are converted into KMD.
4. Once "accumulated amount is of 1$ million worth of revshares" a payout occurs, and everyone gets a percentage of the fees returned to them.

My questions are 1. how do you know what addresses to send the reward KMD to? 2. how do you know how much to send to each address?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a snapshot of the DEX blockchain is made

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that allows to solve both Q1 and Q2

Author: luke#8628
Content: ah, yes makes sense. thanks

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
@jl777c I got the incorrect pubkey issue working but I'm nw getting this when trying to broadcast the TX

```
16: mandatory-script-verify-flag-failed (Script evaluated without error but finished with a false/empty top stack element). Code:-26
```

What does this error mean? That the signature is invalid? I‚Äôm definitely passing the correct derivation path for the input to the Ledger and the pubkey in `scriptSig` matches the pubkey for the input. Any ideas?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it means the signature was not valid. either you are signing the incorrect sigtxid or using the wrong privkey

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: That's really odd, as far as I can see I'm definitely using the correct privkey

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: there are no hardcoded values, I'm requesting the address from the Ledger device, looking up the available UTXOs on insight, and then sending them to the same address

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: This is the full tx:

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: does anything stand out to you as obviously wrong?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
This is going from `RMqevVxyUkgJdSqYEKj5CK4XcX5UvqFsyj` to `RMqevVxyUkgJdSqYEKj5CK4XcX5UvqFsyj` which is the address for the derivation path `"44'/141'/0'/0/0"` on my Ledger.

The Ledger shows the pubkey as `04e4f4b2a6fc1b0b04ae652a961658802c94ffdbe5203ff45466b583c2ac6ec4eb56aaf9d686b1f2035f9f45e63fa156a1bea03cdd67bf20d1735a9cb36c3632c8` which when compressed is `02e4f4b2a6fc1b0b04ae652a961658802c94ffdbe5203ff45466b583c2ac6ec4eb` which matches the pubkey in `scriptSig`.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: locktime isnt set

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the signing is against a modified tx, I call it is sigtxid, which takes the scriptSig and puts the scriptPubKey there of the entire tx, including nLockTime

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if part of the code things nLockTime is set and created the sigtxid based on that, you are signing the wrong sigtxid

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: signing things properly is the biggest painfullest thing there is

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: Yep, learning that the hard way

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: From what I understood I thought locktime was required for the UTXO to accrue rewards, but a TX is still valid without it, it just won't accrue rewards

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: is that incorrect?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I was leaving out locktime for now because I just wanted to get the simplest TX possible signed by the Ledger

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I just tried setting the locktime parameter in the Ledger library to 777, the resulting signed TX looks different but still gets rejected with the same error

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is still valid

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the vin is a p2pkh and the pubkey matches, and the error indicates it is past the pubkey check, so the signature is failing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the three possible ways it can fail is invalid signature from valid privkey, invalid privkey, the wrong thing is being signed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the first would be rare and doubt it is happening with an already working system

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: second is likely not the issue as i am assuming the same automatic mechanism that is adding the pubkey is doing the signing, and they are a matched pair

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: which means it is most likely the sigtxid being wrong and likely it wont printout what it is actually signing, but that is the next step to see what the sigtxid it is signing is and compare it to what it should be

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/OP_CHECKSIG explains in detail how the sigtxid is calculated

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: ok, thanks, will look into that

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I can't really print anything out because all the signing is happening on the device

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: Do you think it would be useful to dump the privkey from the Ledger, try and create and sign a transaction on my machine using the same key/UTXO and see if it it's valid

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: then if it is compare the two

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: that might give us some pointers where the Ledger TX is going wrong

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: signatures are non-deterministic, but if you can sign it on your system, then that eliminates the second issue and makes it pretty certain that the sigtxid is the problem

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: Manually crafting the TX on my machine works and doesn't get rejected

Author: lukechilds#2707
lukechilds#2707
Content: https://www.kmdexplorer.io/tx/52c639ced3eaa5f94f1cc0d63ee84cbed6581d2dfa0df4c394e9157319613ff7

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: didn't get rejected

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
What do you mean by "signatures are non-deterministic"?

That the same input will result in a different signature? Because on the Ledger and on my machine, the same input results in the same output each time.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: well, it depends on the entropy that is input, it could be deterministic

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: based on a specific implementation

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but this indicates the ledger is signing the wrong rawtx

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: sorted it!

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I was manually creating the output script for the ledger TX

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: and I had some null bytes on the end

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it does need to be 100% precise to the bit

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: glad it is sorted

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: yeah, thanks a lot for your help üôå

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
First ever reward claim transaction signed from a Ledger!!!
https://kmdexplorer.io/tx/a058096f1996e5cc6c422c35fc0af08bf54c4eff6583fbbfa5396cd8a8c62b98

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nLicktime needs to be a unixtimestamp

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: why is nLocktime required btw?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I don't quite understand

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: why can't all UTXOs be claimed and just use the block height they were confirmed as their age

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: speed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: things are slow enough as it is, without required block lookups

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: CCduration uses the timestamp in the block

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: but `txheight` is already used in quite a few places in the interest calculations

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
so instead of

```
minutes= (tiptime - nLockTime) / 60)
```

it would be

```
minutes= (tipheight - txheight)
```

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: at the time i couldnt be 100% sure in the accuracy, also height difference only approximates minutes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: anyway, it is done and consensus is based on this, to change it would break consensus and create an entire update, for minimal gains

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: yeah, not advocating to change it, just wanted to understand why it's like this

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it was done years ago

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: before I had a 100% assured way of having the block timestamp

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also, it allows to implement mempool expiration without changing tx serialization

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: ok

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: and re setting the nLocktime to a unix timestamp

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: can I just use the current time or should it be slightly in the future?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: is there a threshold where a nLocktime is too old and it won't get mined or will be rejected?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: slightly in the past

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: cant be more than an hour in the past

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: ok

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: doesn't that mean someone can just set nLocktime to 59 minutes in the past and claim after 5 minutes and rinse and repeat?
